review_title: A great Charity to work for
pros:
I have been working for Newlife very happily for over 8 years so I was very concerned to hear and then read the very negative comments that have been made about this wonderful charity.

I believe that everyone is treated fairly whether you work in the offices, on the sales floor or in the warehouse.  Newlife is a very family friendly organisation and I find all the management, staff and departments I have contact with to be very helpful and supportive.
cons: None that I can think of but we probably all have the odd bad day now and then  but who doesn't.

pros:
In all departments across the organisation, there is passion, commitment and drive to change the lives of disabled children. It is a great place to work, but as with all workplaces there are individuals who struggle to change ways they work even though it is in the best interests of family’s who need charitable services.
There are a large proportion of people who have worked at Newlife a very long time, which speaks very highly of the stability in the organisation but can result in unskilled people taking a personal ownership that limits the charity’s ability to proactively improve systems that offer greater support.
I would highly recommend working at Newlife.
cons: Communication could be better, but the executive team strive to realise opportunities for improvement in the face of adversity.

review_title: Great place to work with passion at the heart.
pros:
The charity has an air of distinctive passion for those who really need the services newlife offers. As a self-sustainable charity where the majority of the income I believe is made through its retail stores and connections to main high street retailers. This gives the organisation a distinct edge but drives the passion for the charity down to its deepest levels. The funds made are pushed through to various charitable activities. I have felt very well supported by the organisation through my employment, my manager always consults me and I feel able to speak up and be heard. The team I work in is close-knit but we know our responsibilities and always welcome new members into the organisation and the team.

The pay-scale isn't always balanced but where recruitment for a job has been necessary to bring in skills for future success, newlife is willing to meet the lower end of pay spectrum for a role, due to its nature (charity) this is absolutely the right way to react to needed growth and skills.
cons:
Sometimes there may be too many things newlife does and spreads its self too thin, a greater visible impact can be had by refining its core objectives.

Some teams often overstep their remits and are not kept in check by middle management, very rarely senior management too, however not the case in the team I work in. 

I have heard from some colleagues recently of troublesome work environments, where team spirit is at an all-time low, poor relationships with Middle Management and Senior Management and this needs to be rectified, or it will poison working environments of those around it. However hard to hear as a believer that the passion the organisation distils is ultimate, this shouldn't be the case and is probably a few bad apples.

review_title: Broad shoulders and do as much research as you can before you take a post in Care Services
pros:
There is no doubt that the aims and ethos of Newlife are admirable. The last resort for many families struggling to cope with the current inadequate social support and lack of essential equipment to make life bearable.
There are many highly qualified people within the organisation who know the systems and will challenge the inadequate care and support. Working at a parliamentary level to change policy.
There is a discount on purchases bought from the retail stores, fairly adequate holiday allowance and a team within a HR remit who do strive to work with the family/disability friendly policies of the company.
On the surface, to other workers in other areas of the Cannock site, Care Services  gives an impression of being well managed, a respectful working environment a place where each individual matters and all work with a common knowledge towards the aims.
cons:
However over the time i have worked there, in excess of 3 years, i have seen many disillusioned workers leave - in administration and allied posts within the care services. Some waiting to gain employment before leaving others walking out or not returning from long term sick. 
There is an increasing attempt by Senior management to make the working environment into one where people are not part of the bigger picture..... being told what to do.....changes without explanation or offering an opportunity to ask why 'there will be no discussion on this'. This approach is not conducive to good working relationships and happy staff. Many say the environment is 'toxic' .....it is one of distrust and a mounting complacency. 
The style of senior management has become dictatorial and worrying.... it appears that one persons mood, beliefs and general attitude is the guiding hand now. 
I could continue with examples of bad practice, people management and lack of respect for the workforce....when i started i felt part of the charity, felt proud but the last year it has become a job to be done because of the background issues. 
These are my observations and my personal opinions.
Please find out as much information as you can if you are thinking of working here. There are many areas to work in so do review within the area you are applying for.....I cannot say what it is like to work in Retail or Communications or HR.  You need to be broad shouldered, not a sensitive soul and get a good description of the job and what prospects are offered or you would expect within the role.
